title: How does Quantum Psychology challenge traditional beliefs about human perception and consciousness?
first_phrase: This text explores the relationship between emptiness and form, and how the body and nervous system interact with the quantum level. The author uses the work of Alfred Korzybski to explain how the perceiving mechanism and nervous system are abstractions of emptiness or the quantum level, but that Korzybski's general semantics has a major error in its omission. The nervous system is a producer of the "I thought," and our psychology comes out of the body, not the other way around. In Quantum Psychology, we understand that different dimensions have an impact, and thoughts come from the body and nervous system through condensation in the Quantum Field.
content: That the nervous system of the body is a trance-former,' trance-kiting (after the fact) the Quantum level OR VOID OF UNDIFFERENTIATED CONSCIOUSNESS--electrons, etc.â€”into experiences. The nervous system "takes" Quantum expe- 'Please note that trance is defined as the shrinking of the focus of attention. During this shrinking process many stimuli and facts are omitted. Thus you (the nervous system) Trance-late the stimuli later after the facts and stimuli are omitted. 129 The Way of the Human Developing Multi-Dimensional Awareness riences which cannot be known to the nervous system and organizes them into the "knower's" experience. 5. The nervous system is the producer of the "I thought" and, hence, the I thought and our psychology come out of the body, not the other way around. In Quantum Psychology we understand that different dimensions have an impact. We also realize that thoughts (maps) come from the body and the nervous system, which comes from a condensation in the Quantum Field OR VOID OF UNDIFFERENTIATED CONSCIOUSNESS.
last_phrase: In conclusion, understanding the role of the nervous system in organizing our experiences and creating our sense of self can lead to a greater awareness of the multi-dimensional nature of our existence. By recognizing the limitations and biases of our thought processes, we can begin to access deeper levels of consciousness and expand our understanding of the world around us. Through this process, we can cultivate a more holistic and integrated approach to personal development and spiritual growth.
